Hey {first_name, "there"}, and welcome to a new week.

A small tweak in format today, as I really wanted to establish a more standard approach to writing these. We kick off with a short piece of context or analysis from me, follow up with a couple of links, and then a recommended long(ish) read, and some music.

Let me know what you think.

sections: Time, reach and the flight to niche
It's easy to slip into thinking of the arrival of the internet as a massive point of discontinuity that disrupted the journalism and publishing worlds.
And, to some extent, that's correct. But the impact has been a

. And no single person, organisation or technology is solely to blame for the woes of the industry. Indeed, it seems likely that our continual quest for a culprit — a scapegoat — might well be a massive distraction from the twin goals of:
Why am I writing about this now?
Two pieces have crossed my radar in recent weeks which have stuck in my head, because they pushed this notions right to the front of my cerebellum once again.

The first was a good post from Om Malik reminding us all of the compex journey that led us to the current media crossroads. We do like to find companies to blame — Google and Facebook, mainly — but the underlying structural issues are just as important. And probably more so.
In my training and consulting work, I find that this unbundling — what I sometimes call
— is one of the most under-appreciated factors in how people consume media.
And if you want to understand the build-up to
situation, Ben Thompson heads back to the 19th century to explore the roots of the current media crisis in how the newspaper and magazine industries developed in the US.
His piece is a good reminder of the
outcome of the current disruption: a small number of very large outlets doing mainstream news (this is the
"winner takes all" part of the subscriptions
) and a much more diverse group of small and micro publishers catering to niches.
An awful lot of businesses are going to die in the transition, though.

One of the most interesting things, from a community management point of view, about the current pandemic is the way it has accelerated change that was already in progress. In particular, it's forced neighbourhoods to start self-orgnaising in a more useful way, as we've all been obliged to spend much more time at home.
